newsitem.title: FRANCE: French Communists lean towards joining government.
newsitem.headline: French Communists lean towards joining government.

text.p: France's Communist Party, back from the cold after a left-wing victory in France's parliamentary election, met on Tuesday amid signs grassroots members wanted to join a Socialist-led government.

The party's policy-making national council, which has opposed a single European currency and wants wage hikes for the low-paid, was discussing conditions for taking part in any government led by new Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin.

The party's 121-member national council also met on Monday after the party won 38 of the 577 National Assembly seats, giving it a balance of power. The non-Communist left won 274 seats -- short of the 289 needed for a majority.

In the Val-de-Marne area that was a bastion of former party leader Georges Marchais, a hardliner who approved the 1979 Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, 88 percent of grassroots Communists voted for participation in government.
Just six percent voted against and six abstained in the biggest Communist Party grouping in France.

Communist Party boss Robert Hue spoke to Jospin on Tuesday and reiterated demands for an immediate 500 franc ($100) hike in the minimum wage, a two percentage point cut in Value Added Tax and bigger cuts in VAT on basic products.
Hue said on Monday that the national council had agreed in principle that Communists should serve in the new government as long as policy questions could be resolved.

Jospin has repeatedly said that anyone wanting to take part in a Socialist-led government would have to bow to the line of the dominant party -- leading to charges by Hue during the campaign that Jospin was trying to impose "hegemony".
The Socialists and Communists signed a pre-election declaration outlining plans to cut the working week to 35 hours from 39 and to create 700,000 youth jobs.
But the Communists want both measures implemented far faster than the Socialists.

Jack Ralite, a former health minister and junior minister for employment in 1981-84, urged the Communists to take part in government. "People are drowning, the Communist Party should roll up its sleeves and do the dirty work," he said.

The 1992 Maastricht Treaty set a course for deeper European political and monetary union, including strict terms for a country's qualification for the euro single currency, due to be launched in 1999.
